block.p: Companies Offer Price Cut For AIDS Drugs in Africa Five pharmaceutical companies are willing to negotiate steep cuts in the prices they charge for AIDS drugs in Africa and other poor regions hard-hit by the disease, the World Health Organization said in Geneva. Major Western drug companies have been under growing international pressure to make their therapies more accessible in poor areas that are grappling with the epidemic.

Sierra Leone Rebels Halted Forces backing the government -- a coalition of United Nations peacekeepers, Sierra Leone soldiers and a militia known as Kamajors -- appeared to push back rebels advancing on the capital, Freetown, as fighting intensified and spread.

Major Western drug companies have been under growing international pressure to make their therapies more accessible in poor areas that are grappling with the epidemic.

Sierra Leone Rebels Halted Forces backing the government -- a coalition of United Nations peacekeepers, Sierra Leone soldiers and a militia known as Kamajors -- appeared to push back rebels advancing on the capital, Freetown, as fighting intensified and spread.
President Clinton said he was sending the Rev. Jesse Jackson to the region to see if he could help negotiate a halt to the violence.

Senate Passes a Trade Bill The Senate approved legislation to promote commerce with Africa and the Caribbean, ending more than five years of defeats on trade bills for the administration. The 77-to-19 vote underscored unusual bipartisan support for a compromise measure. The legislation goes to President Clinton, who is expected to sign it.

Russian Raid on Media Empire Government agents wielding guns and wearing black masks staged a raid on the downtown headquarters of Russia's largest private media empire, Media-MOST, raising concern among politicians and journalists about prospects for an independent press under President Vladimir V. Putin.

Russian Convoy Is Ambushed Islamic rebels mounted a major attack outside Chechnya's borders for the first time in nearly nine months, killing 18 of 22 Russian soldiers in a convoy as it moved down a mountain road in the Caucasus foothills in midmorning. Three soldiers were wounded and one was missing.

Union Warns Gore on China George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said organized labor's support for Vice President Al Gore could be hurt by his recent lobbying for the China trade legislation.

New Mexico Fire Prompts Evacuations and Questions A wildfire forced the evacuation of as many as 25,000 people and destroyed at least 260 homes, but apparently caused no serious damage at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, where nuclear weapons are designed. The fire was started by the Park Service to clear underbrush, and a superintendent was placed on administrative leave, pending an inquiry.

Hearing in Cuban Boy's Case Three judges on a federal appeals court in Atlanta heard arguments on whether immigration officials should hold an asylum hearing for Elian Gonzalez. The judges indicated their decision would take weeks.
Public Lands Bill Passes The House easily approved a measure that set aside $45 billion over 15 years to buy parks and open spaces, pay for wildlife protection and restore damaged coastal areas.

Quotas and Skilled Immigrants President Clinton proposed an increase of more than 85 percent in the number of skilled foreign workers who could be admitted to the United States to fill high-tech jobs.
Survey on Gun Issues Overall support for restrictions on guns has declined in the last two months, mostly because men have grown increasingly sympathetic toward the rights of gun owners.

Maine Acts to Curb Drug Prices The Legislature gave final passage to a bill that makes Maine the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls, and in the meantime effectively turns the state into a giant drug-price negotiator for about half its people.

Gay Unions and Clergy Rejected United Methodist leaders affirmed their opposition to ordination of active homosexuals and to the blessing of same-sex unions. They also voted to uphold a church doctrine that ''the practice of homosexuality is incompatible with Christian teaching.''

Auction House Cancels Sale Leland's voided the $551,841 sale of a basketball offered as the one Wilt Chamberlain used to score his 100th point in a 1962 game. Officials cited challenges to its authenticity.

Giuliani Wards Off Queries On Senate and Private Life Mayor Giuliani said he had not yet decided if he would stay in the Senate race and brushed aside questions about whether he had had an affair with a former aide, as the mayor's wife suggested on Wednesday.
The former aide, Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, said she never had a sexual relationship with Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Giuliani's difficulties have led Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign to shift to a low-key strategy.
O'Connor's Successor Named The Vatican said Bishop Edward Michael Egan, 68, of Bridgeport, Conn., would be archbishop of New York.
New Jersey Senate Debate Former Gov. Jim Florio put Jon S. Corzine on the defensive for a full hour as the two Democrats went head-to-head for the first time.

Early Emigrants From Africa Scientists digging in the republic of Georgia found 1.7-million-year-old human skulls bearing signs of African ancestry, perhaps representing the species that first left Africa.

Report on Malathion An E.P.A. analysis found ''suggestive evidence'' that the insecticide, sprayed in New York City last year to kill disease-carrying mosquitoes, could cause cancer in lab animals, but no evidence that it posed a threat to people when used properly.
Findings on Air Pollution A federal environmental report showed that power plants and other industries had emitted far more toxic chemicals into their surroundings than previously documented.
Auto Emissions Model Disputed The E.P.A.'s computer model for predicting how much air pollution comes from cars and trucks underestimates emissions, the National Academy of Sciences said.
New Editor of Medical Journal Dr. Jeffrey M. Drazen, a leading asthma researcher at Harvard with strong ties to the drug industry, was named editor of The New England Journal of Medicine.

Conceding S.U.V. Drawbacks Ford acknowledged that sport utility vehicles contributed more than cars to global warming, emitted more smog-causing pollution and endangered other motorists. But Ford said it would keep building them because they were so profitable, though it would try to seek technological solutions to the problems and look for alternatives to the big vehicles.

Shake-Up Atop Xerox Xerox, which has been besieged by competition and a battered stock price, ousted its chief executive, G. Richard Thoman; Chairman Paul A. Allaire will assume Mr. Thoman's duties for now. Xerox also named Anne M. Mulcahy, head of its General Markets Organization, as president and chief operating officer.
A Near-Admission in Manila A 23-year-old computer student, Onel de Guzman, all but admitted that he had created the program that crippled e-mail systems.

Fraud Suspect Defends Actions Martin R. Frankel, accused of masterminding a huge American insurance fraud, said in an interview in a German jail that he had really been trying to feed the world's hungry.
Stocks Advance Broadly The Dow rose 1.7 percent, the Nasdaq jumped 3.4 percent and the S.& P. 500 climbed 1.8 percent.
